Award.AwardTitle: FMitF: Track I: Formally Verified Sandboxing for Packet-Processing Programs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration: Modern computing applications process vast amounts of data by<br/>collaboratively employing many thousands of server machines residing<br/>in computing clusters. To support such applications, the network<br/>interconnecting servers and the packet-processing software on the<br/>servers should be fast (supporting high data rates and low delays),<br/>flexible (enabling diverse data-processing applications), and safe<br/>(e.g., programs must run without crashing). Berkeley Packet Filter<br/>(BPF) has emerged as a mechanism to meet these goals and accelerate<br/>novel high-performance packet-processing applications. BPF is<br/>currently deployed in many production systems. BPF achieves<br/>flexibility and performance by running user-developed programs in the<br/>context of the operating system. To ensure safety of such applications, this project will<br/>develop provably-correct static analyzers for BPF programs, protecting<br/>the operating system from security vulnerabilities, denial-of-service<br/>attacks, and crashes. This project will advance the state-of-the-art<br/>in the static analysis, program synthesis, and testing of networking<br/>applications such as load balancers, packet filters, and performance<br/>monitors. This project will also educate graduate, undergraduate, and<br/>high-school students on foundational techniques for reasoning about<br/>correctness, network monitoring, and filtering.<br/><br/>This project has three technical goals. The first is to develop a<br/>verified Berkeley Packet Filter (BPF) static analyzer based on an abstract interpretation that is<br/>correct by construction. The project will address key intellectual<br/>challenges involving the formalization of the BPF instruction set and<br/>modeling of domain-specific sandboxing properties. Currently, an<br/>in-kernel BPF static analyzer checks the safety of loaded BPF programs<br/>by performing range-tracking, memory safety, and freedom from<br/>information leaks. However, this analyzer has deficiences, resulting in the<br/>execution of unsafe programs and exploitable vulnerabilities. The<br/>second goal of this project is to develop an analyzer in the C<br/>programming language that can be usable as part of the kernel, by<br/>leveraging differential analysis, program synthesis, and testing. The<br/>final goal is to design a verified BPF toolchain based on LLVM, by<br/>developing validated translators from C to BPF bytecode.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
